questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of worsening depressive symptoms over the past three months. She currently attends graduate school in the Northeastern United States and has noticed her grades declining over the past month. She was started on sertraline two months ago after experiencing symptoms of low mood, poor academic performance, increased sleep, increased appetite, carbohydrate craving, and weight gain. She has a previous history of recurrent depressive episodes that typically begin in late November and improve by early April. She has had no episodes of persistently elevated or irritable mood or persistently increased activity or energy. Vitals and physical examination are within normal limits. The patient is provided with medications and psychotherapy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with a seasonal pattern

questions.solution:
This patient has been experiencing recurrent episodes of major depression during the winter months with remission by spring, suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD) with a seasonal pattern (also called seasonal affective disorder [SAD]). SAD is a mood disorder with depressive symptoms that occurs at a specific time of year with full remission at other times of the year. It most commonly occurs during fall or winter, although a less common form occurs during spring or summer. The criteria for MDD with a seasonal pattern according to the DSM-V is as follows:
 
  •  Regular temporal relationship between the onset of a major depressive disorder and a particular time of the year 
  •  Full remission at a particular time of year (typically spring or summer months) 
  •  2 depressive episodes in the last 2 years reflecting the seasonal relationship 
Risk factors for SAD include notable family history, female sex, living at a northern latitude, and young adulthood (18 to 30 years of age). The pathophysiology of SAD remains uncertain, but current theories postulate underlying circadian rhythm disruption, dysregulation of the melanopsin signaling pathway and negative impact on serotonin reuptake, and dysfunction of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. The primary treatments for SAD include antidepressants, light therapy (e.g., bright light therapy, dawn simulation), and psychotherapy. 

Option Analysis

✅ Major depressive disorder with a seasonal pattern   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Major depressive disorder   :
Incorrect: Major depressive disorder (MDD) and MDD with a seasonal pattern differ in that symptoms tend to improve in the summer and spring months. Patients with isolated MDD tend to have stable symptoms throughout the year.   
❌ Persistent depressive disorder   :
Incorrect: Persistent depressive disorder, previously called dysthymia, is a chronic depressive state defined by a depressed mood for ≥2 years, along with ≥2 other depressive symptoms. This patient’s depressed mood has been present for <2 years.   
❌ Adjustment disorder with depressed mood   :
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is marked by a depressed mood that occurs in response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor (e.g., new baby, relationship conflicts, job loss). Adjustment disorder is only diagnosed when a patient’s condition does not meet the criteria for another psychiatric disorder.   
❌ Dependent personality disorder   :
Incorrect: Dependent personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive and excessive need to be taken care of–resulting in submissiveness, clinging behavior, and fear of separation. Personality disorders are present throughout life (typically starting in early adulthood). This patient’s symptoms are more consistent with major depressive disorder with a seasonal pattern.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to his primary care physician by his sister for evaluation of depressed mood over the past year. The patient lost his spouse in a car accident 18 months ago when she was driving alone, and since then he has become withdrawn and socially isolated. The patient frequently states, “I could have prevented her death.” He feels intense guilt, stating, “I should have been more protective of her.” He has no changes in appetite, sleep disturbance, or suicidal ideation. He reports difficulty concentrating at work as a store manager and has had to take multiple days off due to poor performance. He has stopped golfing with his friends, an activity he previously enjoyed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s prolonged grief (>12 months following a significant loss), persistent yearning, feelings of guilt, and social isolation are diagnostic of persistent complex bereavement disorder (also known as complicated grief or complex grief).

Acute grief refers to the typical response to loss; in contrast, complicated grief is an aberrant response that occurs in ~10% of patients, with higher rates among individuals who are grieving after a disaster or after a violent or sudden death. Increased rates of complicated grief are also observed in those who have lost a spouse or a child. Complicated grief is associated with clinically significant distress and impairment that affects work-related activities, social functioning, sleep, and daily activities. In addition, patients may also experience suicidal ideation and increased use of alcohol or illicit substances.

Complicated grief is treated with psychotherapy–specifically geared towards helping the patient come to terms with the loss and identify strategies for re-engagement in normal life.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Complex bereavement disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Normal grief   :
Incorrect: Normal and complex bereavement disorder share several overlapping features including sorrow and persistent thoughts of the deceased. Complex bereavement disorder is distinguished by severe symptoms and impaired functioning that persist beyond societal norms, typically at least 6 to 12 months following the death of a loved one. This patient is experiencing debilitating feelings of grief (e.g., social isolation, impact on work) for an extended period of time, making complex bereavement disorder more likely.   
❌ Major depressive disorder   :
Incorrect: Sadness, crying, guilt, sleep disturbance, suicidal thinking and behavior, and social withdrawal occur in both complex bereavement disorder and major depression. The two disorders differ in that complicated grief centers upon the loss of a loved one, whereas sadness secondary to depression is pervasive. Furthermore, this patient does not meet the criteria for the diagnosis of major depression.   
❌ Post-traumatic stress disorder   :
Incorrect: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) involves fear and hypervigilance in response to intrusive flashbacks and distressing memories of a specific traumatic event. Complex bereavement disorder is instead characterized by sadness and yearning.   
❌ Persistent depressive disorder   :
Incorrect: Persistent depressive disorder, previously called dysthymia, is a chronic depressive state defined by a depressed mood for ≥2 years, along with ≥2 other depressive symptoms. This patient’s depressed mood has been present for <2 years and is focused on his spouse’s death, making another diagnosis more likely.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of low energy and depressed mood for the past two months. The patient states her husband died in a car accident several months ago, and since then she has felt unmotivated and tired despite getting 8-hours of sleep per night. She says, “His death was my fault. I’m a failure and nothing will ever change that.” She has had an increased appetite and has gained 6.8-kg (15-lb). She describes difficulty falling asleep, and when she does fall asleep, she often awakens very early in the morning. She states her mood improves when she spends time with her children and sometimes even feels like her “normal self.” However, she quickly returns to a depressed mood hours later. She used to enjoy cycling but states it is unlikely to bring her joy again. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a woman who makes poor eye contact and speaks slowly. The remainder of the examination is non contributory. The presence of which of the following features suggests an increased risk of failure with the first-line pharmacotherapy for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient meets the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD), as indicated by her depressed mood, low energy, anhedonia, early-morning awakenings, weight loss, and psychomotor slowing. She also has mood reactivity, which is a core feature of atypical major depression, a type of depression more likely to fail treatment with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).

A major depressive episode is a period lasting at least two weeks, with five or more of the following symptoms: depressed mood, anhedonia, insomnia or hypersomnia, changes in appetite or weight, psychomotor retardation or agitation, low energy, poor concentration, thoughts of worthlessness or guilt, and recurrent thoughts about death or suicide; at least one of the symptoms must be depressed mood or anhedonia.

According to DSM-5, the core feature of atypical major depression is mood reactivity (i.e. feeling better in response to positive events). Other common features of atypical depression include increased appetite or weight gain, hypersomnia, heavy or leaden feelings in limbs, and longstanding patterns of interpersonal rejection sensitivity. Atypical depression was indoctrinated as a separate diagnosis because clinical trials demonstrated that patients with the atypical features responded better to monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) and SSRIs (the first-line treatment for MDD) were more likely to fail.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reactivity to pleasurable stimuli   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Loss of interest   :
Incorrect: Anhedonia is one of the core qualifying symptoms of a major depressive episode; in fact, in order to diagnose major depression, at least one of the five qualifying symptoms must be a depressed mood or anhedonia. This patient has a different feature suggestive of atypical depression.
❌ Impaired concentration   :
Incorrect: Impaired concentration is a feature of typical depression. This patient has a different feature suggestive of atypical depression.   
❌ Feelings of worthlessness   :
Incorrect: Feelings of worthlessness is a feature of typical depression. This patient has a different feature suggestive of atypical depression.   
❌ Early morning awakening   :
Incorrect: Early morning awakening is a feature of typical depression. This patient has a different feature suggestive of atypical depression.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her partner for evaluation of odd behavior. They state that over the past week, she has been calling old friends from college and high school to “catch up” and invest in a new business for rescuing abandoned dogs. The patient states she recently became passionate about animal abuse and wants to “end the suffering of all dogs.” Her partner found her journal which described an extensive plan to break into pet stores and set the animals free. She has been sleeping for 2-3 hours/night for the past week to work on her new business. The patient’s past medical history includes major depression during college. She does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Urine toxicology is positive for tetrahydrocannabinol. Mental status examination reveals a fidgety woman, pacing back and forth. Her speech is loud, pressured, and accelerated. Her thought process is disorganized. She describes her mood as “the best it's been in years.” There is no suicidal or homicidal ideation. She denies hearing voices or hallucinations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bipolar disorder refers to a chronic mood disorder characterized by fluctuations in both mood and energy. Mood disorders can be classified along a spectrum defined by the extent and severity of mood elevation/depression, ranging from unipolar depression to bipolar I. Patients with unipolar depression present with depressive episodes only, whereas those with bipolar I and bipolar II disorder demonstrate episodes of elevated mood. This patient’s manic episode makes bipolar I the most likely diagnosis.

The diagnosis of hypomanic and manic episodes require elevated/irritable mood and increased energy, in addition to three of the following (four if mood is irritable):
 
  •  D - Distractibility  
  •  I - impulsivity (e.g., buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, foolish business investments) 
  •  G - Grandiosity (inflated self-esteem) 
  •  F - Flight of ideas (e.g. racing thoughts)  
  •  A - Activity (e.g., increase in goal-directed activity, psychomotor agitation) 
  •  S - Sleep (decreased need, feels rested after only a few hours of sleep) 
  •  T - Talkativeness/pressured speech 
A manic state results in severe impairment in daily function, often encroaching on those around them (e.g., family member, spouse). In contrast, a hypomanic episode is characterized by a milder elevation in mood and goal-oriented activities without severe impairment in social function. In some cases, hypomania may improve occupational functioning due to increased productivity.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bipolar I disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Bipolar II disorder   :
Incorrect: Bipolar II disorder is characterized by episodes of major depression and hypomania.  Hypomania is characterized by a milder elevation in mood and goal-oriented activities. This patient’s presentation is suggestive of a manic episode.   
❌ Brief psychotic disorder   :
Incorrect: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by sudden onset of ≥1 psychotic symptom with full remission within one month. This patient’s symptoms (e.g., elevated mood, pressured speech) are more suggestive of a manic episode.   
❌ Schizophrenia:
Incorrect: Schizophrenia is characterized by negative symptoms (e.g., flat affect, poverty of speech, and apathy) as well as positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized thinking) for at least six months. This patient’s symptoms (e.g., elevated mood, pressured speech) are more suggestive of a manic episode.   
❌ Substance-induced mood disorder   :
Incorrect: This patient has a positive urine drug screen for tetrahydrocannabinol (e.g. marijuana); however, it is an unlikely culprit of this patient’s manic symptoms. Marijuana intoxication manifests with euphoria, increased appetite, and psychomotor slowing.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of depressed mood for the past several years. He states that since his mother's passing three years ago he has been constantly tired despite getting 7-8 hours of sleep per night. He rarely socializes stating, “I don’t think I’ll ever find love–I’m unattractive and unable to do anything correctly.” His mood improves when he goes hiking, and he has been going more frequently. He has no suicidal thoughts, changes in appetite, or weight changes. He has no significant past medical history. His younger sister has bipolar disorder. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals an adult male patient who makes poor eye contact. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic depressive symptoms and meets the criteria for persistent depressive disorder (previously called dysthymia). The diagnosis of persistent depressive disorder requires a depressed mood for ≥2 years and ≥2 other depressive symptoms (listed in the table). Antidepressants and psychotherapy, used alone or in combination, are the primary treatments for persistent depressive disorder.



Option Analysis

✅ Persistent depressive disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Major depressive disorder   :
Incorrect: Major depressive disorder is a period lasting at least two weeks, with five or more of the following symptoms: depressed mood, anhedonia, insomnia or hypersomnia, change in appetite or weight, psychomotor retardation or agitation, low energy, poor concentration, thoughts of worthlessness or guilt, and recurrent thoughts about death or suicide; at least one of the symptoms must be depressed mood or anhedonia. This patient does not meet criteria for MDD, and his symptoms have been present for several years, making persistent depressive disorder a more appropriate diagnosis.   
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism is an important underlying medical condition that can mimic symptoms of major depression. This patient does not have other characteristic signs of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight changes, cold intolerance).
❌ Adjustment disorder with depressed mood   :
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is marked by a depressed mood that occurs in response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor (e.g., new baby, relationship conflicts, job loss). Adjustment disorder is only diagnosed when a patient’s condition does not meet the criteria for another psychiatric disorder. This patient’s depressive symptoms do relate to his mother's passing, but the chronicity of his depressive symptoms meet the criteria for persistent depressive disorder.   
❌ Avoidant personality disorder   :
Incorrect: Avoidant personality disorder involves feelings of low self-esteem; however, this patient has additional depressive symptoms, including low energy and depressed mood.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, is brought to the office by her partner for evaluation of low energy and persistent fatigue. She recently gave birth via vaginal delivery three weeks ago; the prenatal period and birth were uneventful, and the neonate has been doing well. She is currently breastfeeding. The patient has been feeling hopeless for two weeks and states, “I don’t know if I can do this anymore.” She has had several episodes of crying “for no reason,” and she attributes it to feeling overwhelmed with her newborn. She sleeps 4-6 hours per day. She used to enjoy attending book club meetings with her friends, but she no longer has an interest in this activity. She has no suicidal or homicidal ideation and has not experienced visual hallucinations or hearing voices. The patient has a history of postpartum blues following her first pregnancy five years ago. She takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination reveals a visibly tired woman. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s depressed mood, low energy, feelings of hopelessness, hypersomnia, and anhedonia are characteristic of a major depressive episode with postpartum onset. Postpartum depression is diagnosed using the same diagnostic criteria for diagnosing major depressive episodes: ≥2 weeks of moderate to severe depression, sleep or appetite disturbance, psychomotor changes, guilt, and suicidal ideation. Screening for postpartum depression should be performed routinely by physicians at postpartum checkups. Onset occurs most often within the first few months of parturition. Management of postpartum depression consists of antidepressants and/or psychotherapy (cognitive-behavioral therapy, interpersonal psychotherapy).

In contrast to postpartum depression, postpartum blues is a condition characterized by mild, self-limiting depressive symptoms (e.g., labile mood, tearfulness) that develop 2-3 days following delivery and resolve by day 10.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.


 

Option Analysis

✅ Postpartum depression   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Postpartum blues   :
Incorrect: Postpartum blues occurs within several days following delivery and is characterized by self-limited symptoms of mood lability and tearfulness. This patient’s symptoms have persisted for more than two weeks.   
❌ Postpartum psychosis   :
Incorrect: Postpartum psychosis is characterized by delusions, hallucinations, or other bizarre behaviors, and can present days to weeks after giving birth. This patient has no evidence of psychotic features.   
❌ Adjustment disorder with depressed mood   :
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is marked by a depressed mood that occurs in response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor (e.g., new baby, relationship conflicts, job loss). Adjustment disorder is only diagnosed when a patient’s condition does not meet the criteria for another psychiatric disorder.   
❌ Post-traumatic stress disorder   :
Incorrect: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) involves fear and hypervigilance in response to intrusive flashbacks and distressing memories of a specific traumatic event. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with postpartum depression.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his partner for evaluation of erratic behavior. Over the past week, he spent several thousand dollars to invest in a new business that will “end world poverty.” He has been sleeping for 2-3 hours/night for the past week to work on his new business. His past medical history includes a major depressive episode during college which resulted in him taking a leave of absence for a semester. He takes no medications currently. Vitals are within normal limits. Mental status examination reveals a man who is unable to sit still and constantly fidgeting. His speech is loud, pressured, and accelerated. He describes his mood as “the best it's been in years.” The patient is provided with a maintenance medication that acts by 5HT<sub>2</sub> and D<sub>2</sub> receptor antagonism. Which of the following medications was most likely provided?
questions.solution:
Bipolar disorder refers to a chronic mood disorder characterized by fluctuations in both mood and energy. Mood disorders can be classified along a spectrum defined by the extent and severity of mood elevation/depression, ranging from unipolar depression to bipolar I. Patients with unipolar depression present with depressive episodes only, whereas those with bipolar I and bipolar II disorder demonstrate episodes of elevated mood. This patient’s manic episode makes bipolar I the most likely diagnosis.

The diagnosis of hypomanic and manic episodes require elevated/irritable mood and increased energy, in addition to three of the following (four if mood is irritable):
 
  •  D - Distractibility  
  •  I - Impulsivity (e.g., buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, foolish business investments) 
  •  G - Grandiosity (inflated self-esteem) 
  •  F - Flight of ideas (e.g. racing thoughts)  
  •  A - Activity (e.g., increase in goal-directed activity, psychomotor agitation) 
  •  S - Sleep (decreased need, feels rested after only a few hours of sleep) 
  •  T - Talkativeness/pressured speech 
Bipolar disorder requires appropriate maintenance therapy with mood-stabilizing medications to decrease the risk of a future recurrence of a manic episode. Medications used in the long-term management of bipolar disorder include lithium, anticonvulsants (e.g., valproate, lamotrigine), as well as second-generation antipsychotics (e.g., quetiapine, lurasidone).

If a patient presents with major depressive symptoms, it is critical to inquire about a previous history of manic episodes/symptoms. If SSRIs are initiated in patients with undiagnosed bipolar disorder they can induce a state of hypomania/mania. 

Option Analysis

✅ Quetiapine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines (e.g. lorazepam) can be used as adjunctive therapy in bipolar patients with persistent anxiety, insomnia, or mild to moderate psychomotor agitation. Lorazepam, however, is not recommended as maintenance therapy for bipolar disorder.   
❌ Haloperidol:
Incorrect: First-generation antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol, chlorpromazine) are used in the treatment of schizophrenia. First-generation antipsychotics are not typically used as long-term, maintenance therapy for bipolar disorder. The medications are strong D2 receptor antagonists with minimal effects on the 5HT2 receptor.   
❌ Fluoxetine:
Incorrect: Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), should be avoided in patients with bipolar disorder due to the risk of precipitating a manic episode.   
❌ Bupropion:
Incorrect: Bupropion, a norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitor, should be avoided in patients with bipolar disorder due to the risk of precipitating a manic episode.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her roommate for evaluation of depressed mood and weight loss. The roommate states the patient has been isolated in their apartment for one month following a failure in one of her college courses. The patient states that she stopped going to classes because she “can’t concentrate for more than 30 minutes.” She no longer plays soccer, which she used to enjoy. The patient has been sleeping for 14 hours per day and states that she still feels tired constantly. She has lost 10-kg (22-lb) over the past month and refuses to eat, even when her friends bring her home-cooked food. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 54/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 98/64 mm Hg. BMI is 17 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals a cachectic woman. The physician recommends a course of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). If ECT is performed, which of the following adverse effects is this patient most likely to experience?
questions.solution:
This patient meets the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD), as indicated by her depressed mood, low energy, anhedonia, impaired concentration, weight loss, and hypersomnia. Her refusal to eat has manifested in evidence of nutritional compromise, suggesting the need for immediate treatment with electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).

ECT is a procedure performed under general anesthesia, where a small electric current induces a generalized tonic-clonic seizure via electrodes placed on the scalp. ECT is regarded as a safe and effective procedure without absolute contraindications. Although the exact mechanism of ECTs role in  improving depression is unknown, growing evidence suggests that it augments neurogenesis and neurotrophic signaling, reversing deleterious atrophic brain changes induced by severe, chronic depression. Indications for ECT include unipolar major depression that:
  
  •  Remains refractory to traditional antidepressant therapy 
  •  Requires rapid treatment, such as during pregnancy, or those with persistent suicidal ideation or refusal to eat resulting in nutritional compromise 
  •  Catatonic depression 
  •  Psychotic features (e.g., delusions, hallucinations) 
While ECT is a safe procedure, many patients experience some adverse cognitive effects after a course of ECT including confusion, anterograde amnesia, and retrograde amnesia.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retrograde amnesia   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Decreased libido   :
Incorrect: Decreased libido is a side effect of many first-line antidepressants (e.g., SSRIs, SNRIs) and is a common culprit behind medication nonadherence. Electroconvulsive therapy has not been shown to induce sexual dysfunction.   
❌ Epilepsy:
Incorrect: Electroconvulsive therapy uses an electric current to produce a generalized cerebral seizure under general anesthesia. Although patients experience seizures during the treatment, there is no evidence to suggest that patients are at an increased risk of developing epilepsy following treatment.   
❌ Progressive dementia   :
Incorrect: Multiple studies have demonstrated that the risk of developing dementia is comparable for patients treated with ECT and those not treated with ECT.   
❌ Increased suicidal ideation   :
Incorrect: There is no evidence to suggest that patients who have undergone ECT are at increased risk of suicidal ideation. In contrast, suicidal ideation is often rapidly relieved by ECT.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for reevaluation of her previously diagnosed major depressive disorder. She started fluoxetine therapy six months ago. Since then, she has had two periods of feeling “great,” describing herself as productive, creative, and sociable, and “able to go all day and night on three hours of sleep.” She works as a salesperson and has recently been considered for a promotion to store manager. She enjoys shopping and has “maxed out her credit cards a few times,” but she has been able to pay her bills in full without issue. She has a past medical history of a major depressive episode during college. She used cocaine in college but has not used it recently. Vitals are within normal limits. Urine toxicology is negative. Mental status examination reveals a pleasant, cooperative woman. Her speech is not pressured. Her thought process is organized. She describes her mood as “the best it's been in years.” Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of elevated mood, increased productivity, and moderately increased risk-taking behavior (e.g. increased credit card spending habits) after initiation of an SSRI (fluoxetine). These features are consistent with a hypomanic episode, secondary to bipolar II disorder. Bipolar II disorder is marked by at least one hypomanic episode, at least one major depressive episode, and the absence of manic episodes.

A manic episode differs from hypomania in that the latter results in significant impairment in daily functioning–often encroaching on those around them (e.g., family member, spouse). In contrast, patients with a hypomanic episode experience a heightened state of energy, activity, and alertness without significant impairment in daily or social functioning. Patients experiencing hypomania may be quick, creative, and productive with an increase in goal-directed activities. In contrast, mania is marked by racing, disconnected thoughts that lead to aimless or ineffective overactivity.

If a patient presents with major depressive symptoms, it is critical to inquire about a previous history of manic episodes/symptoms. If SSRIs are initiated in patients with undiagnosed bipolar disorder they can induce a state of hypomania/mania.

Option Analysis

✅ Bipolar II disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Bipolar I disorder   :
Incorrect: Bipolar I disorder is characterized by manic episodes. A manic state typically results in severe impairment in activities of daily functioning. This patient’s mood elevations are not significantly impairing her functioning, which suggests a hypomanic state.   
❌ Substance-induced mood disorder   :
Incorrect: Acute cocaine intoxication can mimic a manic episode. This patient has a negative urine toxicology screen.   
❌ Cyclothymic disorder   :
Incorrect: Cyclothymic disorder involves two years of fluctuating periods of mild depressive symptoms and hypomania that do not meet full criteria for a hypomanic, manic, or major depressive episode.   
❌ Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder   :
Incorrect: Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder involves a pervasive pattern of preoccupation with perfectionism, orderliness, rigid rules, and control. This patient’s symptoms are more consistent with bipolar II disorder.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to her physician for evaluation of weight gain and low energy for the past two months. The patient broke up with her partner several weeks ago and since then has felt unmotivated and tired despite getting 8-hours of sleep nightly. She used to enjoy rock climbing but no longer finds joy with this activity since it reminds her of all the times she climbed with her ex. She has gained 4.5-kg (10-lb) over this period and has been eating more. She had a similar episode of low mood and energy when she was in college. She takes no medications. She used marijuana occasionally in college but has not used it since. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. The physician and patient discuss several treatment options for depression and agree on combination treatment with both cognitive behavioral therapy and medication. Which of the following questions should the physician ask prior to initiating first-line pharmacotherapy for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: “Have you ever experienced a period of increased activity or energy?”
“Have you used illicit drugs in the past month?”
“Do you have any history of an eating disorder?”
“Do you have a history of elevated blood pressure?”

questions.solution:
This patient meets the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD), as indicated by her depressed mood, low energy, anhedonia, and weight gain. In patients with unipolar depression, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are the first-line treatment, along with concomitant psychotherapy.

When initiating pharmacotherapy for MDD with SSRIs, it is of utmost importance to determine if the patient has a history or symptoms of mania. If SSRIs are initiated in patients with undiagnosed bipolar disorder, they can induce a state of hypomania/mania. Therefore, these patients should be first screened with questions related to a past history of increased energy or activity, since bipolar disorder is better managed by alternative medications (e.g. lithium).

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ “Have you ever experienced a period of increased activity or energy?”:
Correct: See Main Explanation   
❌ “Did you experience childhood trauma?”   :
Incorrect: Understanding this patient’s social history may help better understand this patient’s major depressive episode; however, it is not critical to ask this question prior to initiating pharmacotherapy with serotonin reuptake inhibitors.   
❌ “Have you used illicit drugs in the past month?”   :
Incorrect: Specific laboratory tests (e.g., urine toxicology, thyroid function tests) can be useful in evaluating patients with new-onset major depressive disorder–specifically, to rule out underlying medical causes of depression.   
❌ “Do you have any history of an eating disorder?”   :
Incorrect: A past history of eating disorders (e.g., anorexia, bulimia nervosa) should be obtained prior to initiating bupropion, an atypical antidepressant, due to its ability to lower the seizure threshold. Atypical antidepressants are not the first-line treatment for major depressive disorder.   
❌ “Do you have a history of elevated blood pressure?”   :
Incorrect: Some antidepressant medication classes, such as SNRIs (e.g., venlafaxine, duloxetine), can elevate blood pressure and should be prescribed with caution in patients with a history of hypertension. SNRIs are not the first-line treatment for major depressive disorder.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, is brought to the office with her newborn child for a routine postpartum evaluation. She gave birth via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery five days ago and is currently breastfeeding. The patient states that since giving birth, she has been increasingly exhausted and forgetful. She reports several episodes of spontaneous tearfulness and attributes it to her poor sleep. She has no suicidal or homicidal ideation. She is not experiencing visual hallucinations or hearing voices. The patient has a history of a major depressive episode in high-school treated with sertraline. She currently takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Mental status examination reveals a visibly tired woman. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Postpartum blues refers to a transient disturbance in mood, occurring in 50-85% of new mothers. The pathogenesis of postpartum blues remains unclear, but many studies suggest it is related to postnatal hormonal changes. Symptoms typically begin 2-3 days following delivery and resolve by day 10. The blues are characterized by mood lability, tearfulness, irritability, anxiety, sleep disturbances, and subjective feelings of confusion (e.g., lack of concentration, absent-mindedness).

Management of postpartum blues includes reassurance and watchful waiting. If symptoms fail to improve within two weeks, or if symptoms worsen, the patient may require treatment with antidepressants or psychotherapy.




Option Analysis

❌ Postpartum depression   :
Incorrect: Postpartum depression is diagnosed using the same diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode and typically occurs within the first few months of parturition. Management consists of antidepressants and/or psychotherapy. This patient’s symptoms have been present for less than one week.   
✅ Postpartum blues   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Postpartum psychosis   :
Incorrect: Postpartum psychosis is characterized by delusions, hallucinations, or other bizarre behaviors which can present days to weeks after giving birth. This patient has no evidence of psychotic features.   
❌ Adjustment disorder with depressed mood   :
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is marked by a depressed mood that occurs in response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor (e.g., new baby, relationship conflicts, job loss). Adjustment disorder is only diagnosed when a patient’s condition does not meet the criteria for another psychiatric disorder.   
❌ Post-traumatic stress disorder   :
Incorrect: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) involves fear and hypervigilance in response to intrusive flashbacks and distressing memories of a specific traumatic event. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with postpartum blues.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of low motivation and low energy for months. The patient's mother died last year from terminal lung cancer, and since that time, she has felt unmotivated and constantly tired. She says, “I can’t stop thinking about her and what else I could have done to help her. She was the most important person in my life and now she's gone.” The patient has been socially withdrawn and has not seen her friends in weeks. She has an increased appetite and has gained 6.8-kg (15-lb). She describes difficulty falling asleep, and when she does fall asleep, she often awakens very early in the morning. She used to enjoy hiking but states that it is unlikely to bring her joy again. She has maintained her current employment as an attorney, is married, and has three healthy children. She reports her family has been a source of support for her. She does not use alcohol or other recreational substances. The patient and the physician decide on a nonpharmacologic treatment that focuses on challenging and changing mental distortions and conduct. Which of the following forms of psychotherapy is this physician recommending?
questions.solution:
This patient meets the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD), as indicated by her depressed mood, low energy, anhedonia, and weight gain, for which cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) has been shown to be highly effective.

Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) refers to a set of interventions that help patients identify and correct distorted, maladaptive beliefs. The core premise of CBT is that maladaptive cognition contributes to the maintenance of emotional distress and behavioral problems. CBT teaches patients strategies to change maladaptive thought patterns by both identifying and adjusting cognitive distortions (e.g., overgeneralizations, catastrophizing).

CBT can be used as monotherapy in the treatment of MDD, although several studies have demonstrated the greatest efficacy when used in combination with pharmacotherapy. CBT can be used to treat a variety of mental illnesses, including depression, anxiety disorders, and obsessive-compulsive disorder.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cognitive behavioral therapy   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Dialectical behavioral therapy   :
Incorrect: Dialectical behavioral therapy (DBT) is used to treat patients with borderline personality disorder. This therapy aims to teach patients healthy coping skills, emotional regulation, and appropriate social interactions.   
❌ Biofeedback:
Incorrect: Biofeedback may be used to improve health, performance, and the physiological changes that often occur in conjunction with changes to thoughts, emotions, and behavior. It is generally not regarded as first-line therapy for the treatment of depression.   
❌ Supportive psychotherapy   :
Incorrect: Supportive psychotherapy is used to reinforce a patient’s ability to cope with stressors and is most commonly employed in low-functioning patients or those in crisis who are at risk of decompensation. This patient is gainfully employed and has a supportive family.   
❌ Motivational interviewing   :
Incorrect: Motivational interviewing is a commonly used form of therapy in patients with substance use disorders. It involves focusing on the patient’s motivation for change while the therapist maintains a nonjudgmental stance. This patient does not have a substance use disorder.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to a clinic for evaluation of low energy and fatigue. He has been stressed since being laid off from work 6 months ago, but he feels he has no motivation to look for new employment. He used to write poetry, but he no longer enjoys it, stating, “I just can’t concentrate long enough to write anything of substance, and every time I try my mind wanders.” His appetite has also decreased, and he has lost 5.4-kg (12-lb) over this time. He awakes early in the morning and has difficulty going back to sleep. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a guarded adult male with slow speech. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased serum levels of c-reactive protein

questions.solution:
This patient meets the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD), as indicated by his depressed mood, low energy, anhedonia, early-morning awakening, weight loss, and psychomotor depression. A major depressive episode is characterized by a period lasting at least two weeks with five or more of the following symptoms: depressed mood, anhedonia, insomnia or hypersomnia, change in appetite or weight, psychomotor retardation or agitation, low energy, poor concentration, thoughts of worthlessness or guilt, and recurrent thoughts of death or suicide; at least one of the symptoms must be depressed mood or anhedonia. Neuroendocrine studies in patients with MDD have demonstrated multiple clinical and subclinical alterations of normal human physiology including:
  
  •  Decreased neural transmission of monoamines (serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine), which can be recalled via the mnemonic “SuNDays are depressing.”  
  •  HPA-axis overactivity, resulting in subclinical hypercortisolemia with various neurotoxic effects, including volume loss in the frontal lobe and hippocampus.  
  •  Alterations in sleep architecture, most notably decreased rapid eye movement (REM) sleep latency and slow-wave sleep.  
P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased neural transmission of monoamines:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Increased REM sleep latency:
Incorrect: Depression can significantly alter sleep architecture; changes include decreased rapid eye movement sleep latency and slow-wave sleep.   
❌ Decreased serum levels of c-reactive protein   :
Incorrect: Hormonal and inflammatory factors have been suggested as potentially influencing a depressive state and depressive symptoms, which explains why many patients with unipolar major depression have increased mean serum levels of peripheral inflammatory markers such as cytokines and c-reactive protein.   
❌ Increased hippocampal volume   :
Incorrect: Depressive episodes are associated with higher levels of cortisol, which has been associated with damage to hippocampal neurons followed by atrophy. Some studies suggest that reduced hippocampal volumes precede the onset of depression.   
❌ Decreased serum cortisol   :
Incorrect: An indicator of chronic stress is elevated HPA-axis activity, typically measured by the presence of elevated serum cortisol levels. Increased, not decreased, serum cortisol levels have been found to be associated with depression.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her father for evaluation of depressed mood and worrisome remarks. The father states the patient has been isolated in her apartment for the past month following a “rough break up” with her long-term partner. She stopped going to work abruptly and no longer gardens, which she previously used to enjoy. The patient has been sleeping for 14 hours per day and states that she still feels tired all the time. She states that when she watches television, the news anchor repeatedly says that the patient “should kill herself” and that she is “worthless.” She has no significant past medical history and no previous history of hallucinations or delusions. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a disheveled, guarded woman. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient meets the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD), as indicated by her depressed mood, low energy, anhedonia, impaired concentration, and hypersomnia. Additionally, this patient is experiencing hallucinations. This additional feature suggests the diagnosis of major depression with psychotic features.

Major depression with psychotic features is a type of unipolar depression that occurs more commonly in females, those that are unemployed, and in patients with a family history of depression. Psychotic features associated with this condition consist of delusions (false, fixed beliefs) or hallucinations (false sensory perceptions, usually auditory). The psychotic features are typically mood-congruent, meaning they are consistent with depressive themes of worthlessness, guilt, and hopelessness. Importantly, suicidal ideation and attempts are more common in patients with unipolar psychotic depression.  First-line acute treatment for major depression with psychotic features includes electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) or combination pharmacotherapy with an antidepressant and an antipsychotic.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Major depression with psychotic features   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Schizoaffective disorder   :
Incorrect: With schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder, psychotic symptoms occur in the absence of major depressive features. This patient’s hallucinations are only present during an episode of major depression, suggesting a different diagnosis.   
❌ Schizophrenia:
Incorrect: With schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder, psychotic symptoms occur in the absence of major depressive features. This patient’s hallucinations are only present during an episode of major depression, suggesting a different diagnosis.   
❌ Adjustment disorder with depressed mood   :
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is characterized by a depressed mood that occurs in response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor (e.g., relationship conflicts, job loss, failure). Adjustment disorder is only diagnosed when a patient’s condition does not meet the criteria for another psychiatric disorder.   
❌ Catatonic depression   :
Incorrect: Catatonic features are characterized by an inability to move normally despite the full physical capacity to do so. This patient does not demonstrate signs of catatonia, which typically manifests with hypokinesia or akinesia.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of suicidal ideation. The patient was brought by her roommate, who found the patient’s journal with notes regarding a detailed suicide plan via a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The patient is currently a junior in college and has been under increased stress due to a recent break-up with her partner and failing two classes this semester. Past medical history is notable for bipolar disorder, cocaine and alcohol use, and depression. She has a history of two prior psychiatric admissions, one due to an attempted suicide during high school and another due to a manic-depression episode. On evaluation the patient is evasive and unwilling to provide any history. Scattered superficial lacerations are noted on the forearms. Given this patient’s presentation, which of the following is the strongest risk factor for suicide completion?
questions.solution:
This patient has multiple risk factors for suicide completion. These include age, substance abuse, depression, endorsed plan for attempt, evidence of self harm, and history of prior attempt. Among these risk factors, the strongest one for suicide completion is a history of prior attempts.

Suicide is the 14th leading cause of global mortality. The most common method of suicide completion in the United States is via firearms. Males have higher rates of suicide attempt and completion. Risk factors for suicide include active psychiatric disorders, lack of social support, hopelessness, and prior suicide attempts (most important risk factor). In addition, a history of high impulsivity and substance abuse increases the risk that suicidal impulses will be carried out.

Interventions to reduce suicide include recognition of these risk factors and guiding patients toward appropriate management. For patients who are at imminent risk for suicidal behavior, management will involve inpatient admission, antidepressant therapy, and counseling by a psychiatrist. In addition, protective factors against suicide include effective coping, problem-solving skills, moral objections to suicide, connectedness with the community, as well as strong and supportive relationships.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.    

Option Analysis

✅ History of prior suicide attempt:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of psychiatric admission:
Incorrect: A history of psychiatric admission and psychiatric disorder increases the risk of suicide completion. However, a history of prior suicide attempts is a stronger risk factor.
❌ Evidence of self-harm:
Incorrect: Evidence of self-harm, such as forearm lacerations, demonstrates an increased willingness to carry out a suicidal act. However, a history of prior suicide attempts is a stronger risk factor.
❌ Female sex:
Incorrect: Males, not females, are at higher risk of suicidal completion.
❌ History of substance abuse:
Incorrect: A history of substance abuse increases the risk of suicide completion. However, a history of prior suicide attempt is a stronger risk factor.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to her physician complaining of low energy and an irritable mood for several weeks. She was recently accepted into a master's program and was ecstatic to begin in the fall semester. Once classes started, she began experiencing feelings of “worthlessness.” Her history is significant for self-described “mood swings,” which consist of several-week periods of productivity and improved mood, followed by several-week periods of fatigue, guilt, and depressed mood. She takes no medications. She drinks 2-3 glasses of wine on the weekends. Physical examination is within normal limits.  Mental status examination reveals a visibly tired woman who often needs questions repeated due to inattentiveness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As defined in the DSM-V, cyclothymic disorder presents with alternating states of depressive and hypomanic symptoms for at least 2 years. During the initial index period, the individual cannot be symptom-free for more than 2 months. If the individual's symptoms become sufficiently severe to meet the full criteria for mania, hypomania, or depression before the two-year duration has been met, a diagnosis of bipolar I or II would be made instead of a diagnosis of cyclothymia.

The mood lability in patients with cyclothymic disorder can have serious consequences for an individual's quality of life and level of functioning. The depressive periods of cyclothymic disorder often involve agitation and feelings of low self-worth and guilt, emotional instability, as well as high levels of irritability and anxiety. Depressive symptoms associated with cyclothymic disorder are more often identified, and clinicians often misdiagnose patients with a pure depressive disorder. In contrast, hypomanic symptoms are often overlooked.

Option Analysis

✅ Cyclothymic disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Bipolar I disorder:
Incorrect: Bipolar I disorder includes manic episodes with or without a previous history of major depressive episodes. A manic episode is characterized by Disability, Impulsivity, Grandiosity, Flight of ideas, increased Activity, decreased Sleep, and Talkativeness. Mania typically causes significant personal impairment which may result in legal problems or hospitalization. This patient does not meet the criteria for a manic episode, making another diagnosis more likely.   
❌ Bipolar II disorder   :
Incorrect: Bipolar II disorder is marked by at least one hypomanic episode (characterized by grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, talkativeness, hyperactivity), at least one major depressive episode (characterized by ≥5 of the following: Sleep disturbance, loss of interest, feelings of Guilt, decreased Energy, impaired Concentration, altered Appetite, Psychomotor agitation, Suicidal ideation). This patient doesn’t fully meet the criteria for either major depressive disorder or hypomania, making another diagnosis more likely.   
❌ Substance-induced mood disorder   :
Incorrect: Although chronic alcohol use can result in mood disorders, this patient is not consuming a significant amount, making this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Major depressive disorder   :
Incorrect: A major depressive episode is characterized by ≥5 of the following: Sleep disturbance, loss of interest, feelings of Guilt, decreased Energy, impaired Concentration, altered Appetite, Psychomotor agitation, Suicidal ideation. This patient doesn’t fully meet the criteria for major depressive disorder, making another diagnosis more likely.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, is brought into the clinic by her partner for evaluation of odd behavior. She delivered a healthy, full-term baby via uncomplicated vaginal delivery ten days ago. Two days ago, she told her partner she thought he was poisoning her food and that the baby was “staring at her strangely.” She states she heard horses galloping outside her bedroom. Her partner states they live in a high-rise apartment building in the city. The patient has been unable to sleep. She has expressed guilt about being a terrible mother, and she has heard voices suggesting that she should hurt herself since she does not “deserve to be a mother.” She has a past medical history of bipolar disorder. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination reveals a visibly tired, guarded woman who suspiciously looks towards the window. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Postpartum psychosis occurs in 0.1-0.2% of patients within the first 2-4 weeks following delivery and is most often seen in patients with underlying bipolar disorder. However, this condition also commonly occurs in patients with underlying major depression with psychotic features, schizophrenia, or schizoaffective disorder. Features include paranoid, grandiose, or bizarre delusions, mood swings, confused thinking, and grossly disorganized behavior. Delusions of postpartum psychosis are typically related to the patient's mood state (e.g., in a depressed state, the patient may believe that the baby is evil or that people close to them are trying to poison them).

In the first year after childbirth, suicide risk increases 70-fold; suicide is the leading cause of maternal death up to one year after delivery. Therefore, patients demonstrating signs and symptoms of postpartum psychosis should be considered for immediate psychiatric hospitalization, as the risk of suicide/homicide (typically infanticide) is much higher in these patients. In addition to hospitalization, patients with postpartum psychosis should be started on antipsychotic medications (e.g., quetiapine, risperidone).

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.


 

Option Analysis

❌ Postpartum depression   :
Incorrect: Postpartum depression is diagnosed using the same diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode and typically occurs within the first few months of parturition. Management consists of antidepressants and/or psychotherapy. This patient has features of disorganized behavior, making another diagnosis more likely.   
❌ Postpartum blues   :
Incorrect: Postpartum blues occurs within several days following delivery and is characterized by self-limited symptoms of mood lability and tearfulness. Management involves reassurance and close monitoring for persistent symptoms.   
✅ Postpartum psychosis   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Adjustment disorder with depressed mood   :
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is marked by a depressed mood that occurs in response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor (e.g., new baby, relationship conflicts, job loss). Adjustment disorder is diagnosed when a patient’s condition does not meet the criteria for another psychiatric disorder.   
❌ Dependent personality disorder   :
Incorrect: Dependent personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive and excessive need to be taken care of–resulting in submissiveness, clinging behavior, and fear of separation. Personality disorders are present throughout life (typically starting in early adulthood).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to his primary care physician's clinic for evaluation of low energy and fatigue. He states he has been more stressed since being laid off from work six months ago. He used to work as an investment banker, and he has not had the motivation to look for a new job. He used to play the piano in his spare time, but he states he no longer enjoys it due to his inability to concentrate. His appetite has increased and he has gained 4.1-kg (9-lb) over this time. He awakens early in the morning and has difficulty going back to sleep. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a young, disheveled man who makes poor eye contact and speaks slowly. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory. The physician discusses several treatment options, and together they agree on combination treatment with cognitive behavioral therapy and sertraline. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Inhibition of norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake

questions.solution:
This patient meets the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD), as indicated by his depressed mood, low energy, anhedonia, early-morning awakenings, increased appetite with weight gain, and psychomotor depression. Initial treatment of unipolar major depression relies on a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy (e.g. cognitive-behavioral therapy). For patients with unipolar major depression, first-line initial treatment includes selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as sertraline.

Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine, is a neurotransmitter that influences multiple central nervous system processes, including cognition, autonomic function, motor activity, as well as affection, mood, and reward. Various alternative antidepressant classes can be used should SSRIs prove ineffective and are listed in the table below.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of 5-hydroxytryptamine reuptake   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Inhibition of norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake   :
Incorrect: Bupropion acts via dual inhibition of both norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake. Sertraline acts via a different mechanism.   
❌ Inhibition of monoamine degradation   :
Incorrect: Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) are responsible for inhibiting the monoamine oxidase enzyme, which breaks down norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine. Sertraline acts via a different mechanism.   
❌ Central presynaptic alpha-2-adrenergic antagonist   :
Incorrect: Mirtazapine works by exerting antagonist effects on the central presynaptic alpha-2-adrenergic receptor, which increases the release of serotonin and norepinephrine. Mirtazapine's ability to antagonize various serotonin receptors (5-HTA, 5-HT3) allows remaining serotonin to interact with the free 5-HT1 receptor. Sertraline acts via a different mechanism.   
❌ Inhibition of inositol monophosphatase   :
Incorrect: Unlike other psychopharmacological agents, lithium does not bind to cellular receptors. Its mechanism remains unclear but is postulated to work via modification of intracellular second messenger systems (such as the phosphatidylinositol (PI) signaling pathway), downstream of metabotropic neurotransmitter receptors, enzyme inhibition. Sertraline acts via a different mechanism.
